across.text: Case made for mummy’s confinement?
across.explanation: SARCOPHAGUS. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole, taking mummy to be of the Egyptian variety. A sarcophagus would be the casket or “case” they would be buried in.

across.text: Land using stone passage we hear
across.explanation: EMERALD ISLE(i.e. “land”, in this case an informal name for Ireland). Solution is EMERALD (i.e. a precious “stone”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “we hear”) of AISLE (i.e. “passage”).

across.text: Engineer reminds open branch to get guard dog
across.explanation: DOBERMANN PINSCHER(i.e. “guard dog”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “engineer”) of REMINDS OPEN BRANCH.

across.text: Conservative member of the House of Lords rebuffed toady
across.explanation: CREEP(i.e. “toady”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “Conservative”) followed by PEER (i.e. “member of the House of Lords”) once this latter has been reversed (indicated by “rebuffed”), like so: C-REEP.

across.text: Journalist having something to learn by holding papers back
across.explanation: EDITOR(i.e. “journalist”). Solution is ROTE (i.e. “something to learn by”) wrapped around or “holding” ID (i.e. “papers”, short for identity). The whole is then reversed (indicated by “back”), like so: ED(IT)OR.

across.text: Dallas Cowboy’s dispute with Republican
across.explanation: WRANGLER(i.e. “Dallas cowboy”, ignoring the misleading capitalisation. We’re not dealing with the American Football team here). Solution is WRANGLE (i.e. “dispute”) followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “Republican”).

across.text: Criticise manoeuvre moving ring in glittering array
across.explanation: PANOPLY(i.e. “glittering array”). Solution is PAN (i.e. to “criticise”) followed by PLOY (i.e. a “manoeuvre”) once the O (i.e. “ring”) has been “moved” like so: PAN-PL(O)Y => PAN-(O)PLY.

across.text: Large settlement of rank furthers claims
across.explanation: FRANKFURT(i.e. a “large settlement”, in this case a city in Germany). “Claims” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: O(F RANK FURT)HERS.

across.text: Repeatedly bomb China
across.explanation: EGGSHELL(i.e. delicate “China”). “Repeatedly” indicates we’re seeking multiple words satisfying “bomb”, in this case EGG and SHELL, the former being slang for a bomb or mine.

across.text: Clubs inspired by United in the past
across.explanation: ONCE(i.e. “in the past”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “clubs” used in some card games) placed in or “inspired by” ONE (i.e. “united”, ignoring the misleading capitalisation), like so: ON(C)E.

across.text: One involved in endless task that is boring vocal group
across.explanation: CHOIR(i.e. “vocal group”). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) placed “in” CHORE (i.e. “task”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “endless”), like so: CHO(I)R.

across.text: Top gangster struggled without cover
across.explanation: HOODIE(i.e. garment or “top”). Solution is HOOD (i.e. “gangster”) followed by VIED (i.e. “struggled”) once the first and last letters have been removed (indicated by “without cover”), like so: HOOD-IE.

across.text: Trap left criminal corporation without millions
across.explanation: LOBSTER POT(i.e. “trap”). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) followed by MOBSTER (i.e. “criminal”) and POT (i.e. “corporation” – we’ve seen this a few times now, a variant meaning of “corporation” is an archaic reference to a pot belly). The M is then removed from all this (indicated by “without millions” – M being a recognised abbreviation of “millions”), like so: L-OBSTER-POT. Very nicely worked.

across.text: Careless fielders at cover dropping ball
across.explanation: SLIPSHOD(i.e. “careless”). Solution is SLIPS (i.e. some “fielders” in a game of cricket) followed by HOOD (i.e. “cover”) once one of the Os has been removed (indicated by “dropping ball”), like so: SLIPS-HOD. Another good un.

across.text: Present that’s small: maybe a foot?
across.explanation: STOCKING FILLER. Solution satisfies a Christmas “present that’s small”, and, playfully, “maybe a foot”.

across.text: Topic has Labour developing fear of being hemmed in
across.explanation: CLAUSTROPHOBIA(i.e. “fear of being hemmed in”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by ”developing”) of TOPIC HAS LABOUR. Another excellent clue.

across.text: Host introducing song with welcome for musician
across.explanation: MARIACHI(i.e. “musician”). Solution is MC (i.e. “host” or Master of Ceremonies) wrapped around or “introducing” ARIA (i.e. a “song”) and followed by HI (i.e. “welcome”), like so: M(ARIA)C-HI.

across.text: Unhappy person reduced masculine subject matter
across.explanation: MALCONTENT(i.e. “unhappy person”). Solution is MALE (i.e. “masculine”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “reduced”) and the remainder followed by CONTENT (i.e. “subject matter”), like so: MAL-CONTENT.

across.text: Charity’s first to move east to set up accommodation
across.explanation: ENCAMP(i.e. “set up accommodation”). Solution is MENCAP (i.e. a “charity”) with the “first” letter “moved east” or to the right – this being an across clue – like so: (M)ENCAP => ENCA(M)P.

across.text: Try to persuade prisoner to avoid scorn
across.explanation: TEMPT(i.e. “try to persuade”). Solution is CONTEMPT (i.e. “scorn”) with the CON removed (indicated by “prisoner to avoid”…)

across.text: Moderate support terminated prematurely
across.explanation: EASE(i.e. to “moderate”). Solution is EASEL (i.e. “support”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “terminated prematurely”).

across.text: Disciplinarian’s right to stop unruly inmate
across.explanation: MARTINET(i.e. “disciplinarian”, apparently after a French general during the reign of Louis XIV). Solution is RT (a recognised abbreviation of “right”, e.g. in the title Rt Hon) placed in or “stopping” an anagram (indicated by “unruly”) of INMATE, like so: MA(RT)INET.

across.text: Bribe small number disrupting series
across.explanation: SWEETENER(i.e. “bribe”). Solution is WEE (i.e. “small”) and TEN (i.e. a “number”) both placed in or “disrupting” SER (a recognised abbreviation of “series”), like so: S(WEE-TEN)ER.

across.text: Scene involving figures primarily in office during crisis
across.explanation: DIORAMA(i.e. “scene involving figures”). Solution is I and O (i.e. “primarily in office”, i.e. the first letters of “in” and “office”) both placed in or “during” DRAMA (i.e. “crisis”), like so: D(IO)RAMA.

across.text: Animal puppet
across.explanation: CREATURE. Solution satisfies “animal” and “puppet”, the latter found fairly deep in CREATURE’s definitions; Chambers has: “a person completely under one’s control, a dependant, instrument or puppet”. A new one on me.

across.text: Vehicle in which one would arrive late?
across.explanation: HEARSE(i.e. “vehicle”). The remainder of the clue plays on how “late” is used to describe someone who is deceased, and how a HEARSE is used to carry the deceased to their funeral.

across.text: Sex appeal of older men perplexes her initially
across.explanation: OOMPH(i.e. “sex appeal”). “Initially” indicates the solution is derived from the initial letters ofOfOlderMenPerplexesHer.

across.text: Aide is not upset about newspaper’s transfer of ownership
across.explanation: DENATIONALISATION(i.e. “transfer of ownership” from the state to the private sector). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “upset”) of AIDE IS NOT wrapped “about” NATIONAL (i.e. “newspaper”), like so: DE(NATIONAL)ISATION.

across.text: Very bright child reportedly drowned
across.explanation: SUN-DRENCHED(i.e. “very bright”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “reportedly”) of SON (i.e. “child”) followed by DRENCHED (i.e. “drowned” or sodden).

across.text: Union member backing protest about time and space for rest breaks?
across.explanation: SITTING ROOM(i.e. “space for rest breaks”). Solution is GROOM (i.e. “union member”, taking “union” to mean a marriage) placed after or “backing” SIT-IN (i.e. “protest”) once wrapped “about” T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: (SIT-(T)-IN)-GROOM.

down.text: Team produces unexpected results?
down.explanation: SIDE EFFECTS(i.e. “unexpected results”). Solution is SIDE (i.e. “team”) followed by EFFECTS (i.e. “produces”). Simple but nicely worked.

down.text: Key books in religious studies: his speciality?
down.explanation: RABBI, the “his” within the context of the clue. Solution is A (i.e. a musical note or “key”), B and B (i.e. “books” – B being a recognised abbreviation of “book”) all placed “in” RI (i.e. “religious studies”, in this case a recognised abbreviation of Religious Instruction), like so: R(A-BB)I.

down.text: What’s fitting for rower from Havard or Yale we’re told?
down.explanation: OARLOCK(i.e. “what’s fitting for rower from Harvard” – an OARLOCK being another word for a rowlock, “a contrivance serving as fulcrum for an oar”(Chambers)). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “we’re told”) of OR followed by LOCK (i.e. “Yale”, a variety thereof).

down.text: Leader deceived about office finally
down.explanation: HEAD(i.e. “leader”). Solution is HAD (i.e. “deceived”) wrapped “about” E (i.e. “office finally”, i.e. the last letter of “office”), like so: H(E)AD.

down.text: Taxonomic groups split into individuals of similar age
down.explanation: GENERATION(i.e. “individuals of similar age”). Solution is GENERA (i.e. “taxonomic groups”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “split”) of INTO, like so: GENERA-TION.

down.text: Literary genre almost fits iconic scene in novel format
down.explanation: SCIENCE FICTION(i.e. “literary genre”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “in novel format”) of FITS once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “almost”) and ICONIC SCENE.

down.text: Anagram aligns with edges of eligible fodder
down.explanation: ENSILAGE(i.e. “fodder” – ENSILAGE can describe silage as well as the process itself). Solution is an anagram (indicated by… er… “anagram”) of ALIGNS and EE (i.e. “edges of eligible”, i.e. the first and last letters of “eligible”).

down.text: Some number subtracted from lower number
down.explanation: ETHER(i.e. “number” or anaesthetic, as in how it numbs). Solution is NETHER (i.e. “lower”) with the N removed (indicated by “some number subtracted from…” – N can be a variable that represents any number).

down.text: Killer returned and cut down European in citadel
down.explanation: ACROPOLIS(i.e. a “citadel”, especially in Athens). Solution is ORCA (i.e. “killer” whale) reversed (indicated by “returned”) and followed by POLISH (i.e. “European”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “cut down”), like so: ACRO-POLIS.

down.text: Becoming fairly good
down.explanation: DECENT. Solution satisfies “becoming” or to look presentable, and “fairly good”. Again, simple but nicely worked.

down.text: What slows up journey having dropped off Bobby?
down.explanation: SLEEPING POLICEMAN(i.e. “what slows up journey”, a speed bump). Solution is SLEEPING (i.e. “having dropped off”) followed by POLICEMAN (i.e. “bobby”, slang thereof).

down.text: Person no longer having to accommodate issue?
down.explanation: EMPTY-NESTER. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole, taking “issue” to mean offspring.

down.text: Game associated with US includes quiet period of heightened activity
down.explanation: RUSH HOUR(i.e. “period of heightened activity”). Solution is RU (i.e. “game”, specifically Rugby Union) and OUR (i.e. “associated with us”, ignoring the misleading capitalisation) wrapped around or “including” SHH (i.e. “quiet” – Chambers allows a second H), like so: RU-(SHH)-OUR.

down.text: A ridiculous ban on women’s lib includes old lady and elusive creature
down.explanation: ABOMINABLE SNOWMAN(i.e. “elusive creature”). Solution is A followed by an anagram (indicated by “ridiculous”) of BAN ON WOMEN’S LIB once wrapped around or “including” MA (i.e. “old lady”, both informal references to one’s mother), like so: A-BOMINABLESNOW(MA)N.

down.text: Get lost, missing first suitable walk
down.explanation: HOOF IT(i.e. to “walk”). Solution is SHOO! (i.e. “get lost”) with its first letter removed (indicated by “missing first”) and the remainder followed by FIT (i.e. “suitable”), like so: HOO-FIT.

down.text: Gathering welcomes little male chauvinist? Hardly
down.explanation: FEMINIST(i.e. “male chauvinist? Hardly”). Solution is FEST (i.e. “gathering”) wrapped around or “welcoming” MINI (i.e. “little”), like so: FE(MINI)ST.

down.text: One opposing current measures is tortured to some extent
down.explanation: RESISTOR(i.e. “one opposing [electrical] current”). “To some extent” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: MEASU(RES IS TOR)TURED.

down.text: Get ready to put TV channels into effect?
down.explanation: ACTION STATIONS. Solution satisfies a call to “get ready” and, playfully, “to put TV channels into effect”, given channels are sometimes also called stations.

down.text: Secures Greek fruit
down.explanation: GRAPPLES(i.e. “secures”). Solution is GR (a recognised abbreviation of “Greek”) followed by APPLES (i.e. “fruit”).

down.text: Way to secure deal for instrument
down.explanation: SPINET(i.e. a musical “instrument” akin to a harpsichord). Solution is ST (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a “street”) wrapped around or “securing” PINE (i.e. “deal” – we’ve seen this a couple of times in Jumbos; a variant definition of “deal” is “a fir or pine board of a standard size”(Chambers)), like so: S(PINE)T.

down.text: Committee introduces conclusion in dutiful summary
down.explanation: COMPENDIOUS(i.e. “summary”, taken as an adjective). Solution is COM (a recognised abbreviation of “committee”) followed by END (i.e. “conclusion”) once placed in or “introduced” to PIOUS (i.e. “dutiful”), like so: COM-P(END)IOUS.

down.text: Lay to rest strange cases for one new breach in rules?
down.explanation: INTERREGNUM(i.e. “breach in rules”). Solution is INTER (i.e. “lay to rest” or bury) and RUM (i.e. “strange”) once wrapped around or “casing” EG (i.e. “for one”, or for example) and N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”), like so: INTER-R(EG-N)UM.

down.text: Attendant’s vehicle, right outside, to the rear of church property
down.explanation: MANSERVANT(i.e. “attendant”). Solution is VAN (i.e. “vehicle”) placed in or having “outside” of it RT (a recognised abbreviation of “right”, already covered). This is all then placed “to the rear of” MANSE (i.e. “church property”), like so: MANSE-R(VAN)T.

down.text: Great Dane wrecked open-air restaurant
down.explanation: TEA GARDEN(i.e. “open-air restaurant”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “wrecked”) of GREAT DANE. Another I really liked.

down.text: Bankrupt’s case undoubtedly involves owing money
down.explanation: INDEBTED(i.e. “owing money”). Solution is BT (i.e. “bankrupt’s case”, i.e. the first and last letters of “bankrupt”) placed in or “involved” by INDEED (i.e. “undoubtedly”), like so: INDE(BT)ED.

down.text: Insect eating through round sea cucumber
down.explanation: TREPANG(i.e. “sea cucumber”). Solution is GNAT (i.e. “insect”) wrapped around or “eating” PER (i.e. “through”, as in the phrase “as per”). The whole is then reversed (indicated by “round”), like so: T(REP)ANG. Bradford’s to the rescue here.

down.text: State hospital opening up in due course
down.explanation: LATHER(i.e. a distressed “state”). Solution is H (a recognised abbreviation of “hospital” used on maps) placed in or “opening up” LATER (i.e. “in due course”), like so: LAT(H)ER.

down.text: Shell company originally needed Switzerland
down.explanation: CONCH(i.e. “shell”). Solution is CO (a recognised abbreviation of “company”) followed by N (i.e. “originally needed”, i.e. the first letter of “needed”) and CH (i.e. country code of “Switzerland”, short for Confederazione Helvetica).

down.text: Horny individual maybe picked up mocking refusal
down.explanation: RHINO(i.e. “horny individual”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “picked up”) of WRY (i.e. “mocking”) followed by NO (i.e. “refusal”), like so: RHI-NO.

down.text: Hide structure from one following advice
down.explanation: TIPI(i.e. “hide structure”, a variant spelling of TEPEE). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) placed after or “following” TIP (i.e. “advice”), like so: TIP-I.
